stem: You are caring for a 62-year-old male patient, Mr. Johnson, who has a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) and an intracranial pressure (ICP) monitoring device in situ. Review the provided patient information and select all of the nursing interventions that are appropriate for this patient.

options.text: Maintain the head of the bed (HOB) at 30-45 degrees.
options.rationale: Elevating the HOB to 30-45 degrees promotes venous drainage from the brain, reducing ICP. This position also aids LVAD function by decreasing preload, as gravity assists venous return. Reduced ICP minimizes the risk of cerebral ischemia and supports optimal cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).

options.text: Routinely flush the LVAD driveline with sterile saline.
options.rationale: Routine flushing of the LVAD driveline is contraindicated as it can introduce infection or damage the device. LVAD driveline care involves meticulous assessment for infection signs (redness, swelling, drainage) and sterile dressing changes per protocol. Unnecessary manipulation increases infection risk.

options.text: Logroll the patient every 2 hours to prevent pressure ulcers.
options.rationale: Logrolling maintains spinal alignment and prevents pressure ulcers, crucial for immobile patients with LVADs and ICP monitors. This technique minimizes shear and friction forces on the skin, reducing the risk of pressure injury, especially over bony prominences. Regular repositioning is vital.

options.text: Administer prescribed stool softeners to prevent straining during bowel movements.
options.rationale: Straining during bowel movements (Valsalva maneuver) increases ICP and intra-abdominal pressure, negatively impacting LVAD function. Stool softeners prevent constipation, reducing straining risk. This action minimizes ICP spikes and ensures stable LVAD performance by avoiding increased afterload.

options.text: Assess neurological status using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) every 4 hours.
options.rationale: Regular GCS assessments monitor changes in consciousness and detect increased ICP signs. Early detection enables timely intervention to prevent neurological damage. A decreasing GCS score indicates worsening neurological function, prompting immediate investigation and management.

options.text: Monitor LVAD parameters and alarms per hospital protocol.
options.rationale: Continuous LVAD parameter monitoring ensures proper device function and detects complications like pump thrombosis or outflow obstruction. Adhering to hospital protocols standardizes safe LVAD management, preventing device malfunction and ensuring patient safety through early detection of deviations.

options.text: Encourage deep coughing and incentive spirometry every 2 hours.
options.rationale: Forceful coughing transiently increases ICP. Gentle coughing and alternative secretion clearance methods are preferred. Incentive spirometry is acceptable if tolerated without significant ICP increase. Aggressive coughing can exacerbate intracranial hypertension, risking neurological compromise.

SBAR.situation: Mr. Johnson, a 62-year-old male with an LVAD and ICP monitor, was admitted for altered mental status. He has a history of heart failure and a recent fall.
SBAR.background: The patient underwent LVAD implantation 6 months ago. An ICP monitor was placed 2 days ago following a witnessed fall at home. Baseline ICP has been between 8-12 mmHg. He is on a continuous heparin infusion per protocol for anticoagulation.
SBAR.assessment: At 08:00, the patient is somnolent but arousable to voice. His GCS is 13 (Eyes 3, Verbal 4, Motor 6). ICP is currently 18 mmHg. LVAD parameters are within normal limits. A neurological exam shows no new focal deficits. Vitals: BP 110/70 mmHg, HR 70 bpm (LVAD-supported), RR 16, SpO2 96% on 2L NC, Temp 37.2Â°C. A small abrasion is noted on his forehead. Pupils are equal and reactive.
SBAR.recommendation: I recommend notifying the neurosurgeon regarding the elevated ICP. Consider ordering a CT scan of the head to rule out new hemorrhage. Evaluate the need for mannitol or hypertonic saline to reduce ICP. Continue close neurological monitoring and LVAD parameter assessment. Strict I/O monitoring is essential. Implement seizure precautions.

clinicalPearls: Patients with LVADs often have a non-palpable pulse; use Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) for blood pressure assessment.
Avoid aggressive coughing or Valsalva maneuvers in patients with elevated ICP to prevent further increases.
Meticulous skin care is crucial to prevent infection in patients with LVAD drivelines and ICP monitoring devices.
questionTrap: Selecting interventions that are generally good nursing care but are contraindicated by either the LVAD or the ICP monitoring.
mnemonic: HEADS UP: HOB elevation, Evaluate neuro status, Avoid straining, Driveline care, Stool softeners, Understand LVAD Parameters, Prevent pressure ulcers.
references: Neurocritical Care Society Guidelines for ICP Monitoring

rationale.correct: All rationales are embedded within the options.
